div1.p: Lhotka explains the procedure for an inter-library loan. He lists all documents containing information on the work of the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Charles L. Lhotka to Philip Showalter Hench, February 4, 1941
div1.opener:
CIVICS AND DOCUMENT DEPARTMENT
THE CHICAGO PUBLIC LIBRARY
C. B. RODEN, LIBRARIAN
February 4, 1941
Dr. P.S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr. Heath,
div1.p:
The procedure for an Inter-Library Loan
is to have the Chief Librarian of the Rochester Public
Library address our Chief Librarian (Mr. Carl B. Roden)
requesting the loan of the material and stating that they
will assume the responsibility for the care and safe return
of same. The library making the request also agrees to
assume the expense of shipping.

The following list of
Documents contains information on the work of the Yellow
Fever Commission that will be useful to you. If these
documents are not available in the Rochester Library you
can ask the Librarian to request them from us in accordance
with the usual Inter-Library Loan form.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours THE CHICAGO PUBLIC LIBRARY
Charles L. Lhotka Chief
Civics and Documents Dept. Report of Brig. Gen. Ludlow
Military Governor of Habana, 1900 W57.1 1900
Report of the War Dept.
For the year 1899 Ames 3900 I have this
61st. Cong. 3rd. sess. Senate rept.
on yellow fever. Ames 5919
71st. Cong 2nd. sess rept. 841
..heroes of the fight against
yellow fever Ames 9191
